body: **Team Decision:** Introduce a new `@EnabledForJreRange` annotation that has optional `min`/`max` attributes to define closed, potentially half open ranges, e.g. `@EnabledForJreRange(min = JAVA_8)`, `@EnabledForJreRange(max = JAVA_11)`, `@EnabledForJreRange(min = JAVA_8, max = JAVA_11)`.
@wilkinsona Would you be interested in submitting a PR?
Yeah, I would, although it'll probably be mid-October before I have time to tackle it.
Alright, I've put it up-for-grabs in case someone else wants to pick it up in the meantime.

i actually would love to try to implement this :D - i will try my best next week, and i will let you know if i think i am able to do this. - but looks pretty straight forward - i will just use the already existing annotations as my inspiration

my Assumption:
- the ordinality of JRE is reliable for version comparison
- JRE.JAVA_8 will always be the lowest version, so i can use it as default for min value
- JRE.OTHER will always be the highest version, so i can use it as default for max value

Question:
- is there also a usecase for `@DisabledOnJreRange`? should i take that into account?
Sounds good and I think there's a use case for `@DisabledOnJreRange`, too! ðŸ‘

Maybe they should be mutually exclusive though, to avoid weird cases?
What should happen if a test combines `@EnabledForJreRange(min = JAVA_8, max = JAVA_11)` and `@DisabledForJreRange(min = JAVA_10, max = JAVA_12)` for instance? ðŸ˜®

I can agree that there might be weird cases, but I think right now there is no exclusivity over `@Disabled*` and `@Enabled*` of the same type. So I can do this theoretically already with just `@EnabledOnJre` and `@DisabledOnJre`. Hence that I would stick to the existing behavior of this functionality.

Furthermore I think it will be difficult to handle, what if a method is annotated with `@DisabledOnJre` and the class with `@EnabledOnJre`. This will get really tricky in my opinion.

> Each of the conditional annotations listed in the following sections can only be declared once on a given test interface, test class, or test method. If a conditional annotation is directly present, indirectly present, or meta-present multiple times on a given element, only the first such annotation discovered by JUnit will be used; any additional declarations will be silently ignored. Note, however, that each conditional annotation may be used in conjunction with other conditional annotations in the `org.junit.jupiter.api.condition` package.

Copied from https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#writing-tests-conditional-execution

That and the lazy evaluation -- the first condition that yields "disabled" wins -- ensures a deterministic behavior. Users may always implement a custom `ExecutionCondition` to apply a logic of their choice.

> What should happen if a test combines `@EnabledForJreRange(min = JAVA_8, max = JAVA_11)` and `@DisabledForJreRange(min = JAVA_10, max = JAVA_12)` for instance? 

I guess it should run on Java 8 and 9... certainly a good way to confuse one's coworkers. ðŸ˜‰

issue.title: Support for enabling or disabling a test on a range of JREs

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Support for enabling or disabling a test on a range of JREs. Therfore we implemented two new annotations `@EnabledForJreRange` and `@DisabledForJreRange` which contain two parameters `min` (Defaults to `JRE.Java_8`)  and `max` (defaults to `JRE.OTHER`). By defaulting those to the highest and lowest version, we allow the usage of half open ranges.

I might need to rework javadoc and documentation, i am not really good when it comes to wording those.

Resolves #2016.

---
